blog.name: thedemonphanti
blog.title: thedemonphanti
blog.description: Treat People With Respect | Unpopular Opinions Welcome

summary: This is why I don’t want Dan to make political videos because he is clearly not educated enough he should stick to comedy 😒😒😒😒😒
question: This is why I don’t want Dan to make political videos because he is clearly not educated enough he should stick to comedy 😒😒😒😒😒
answer:
While I love Dan’s comedy, I don’t think he (or anyone) should have to be boxed into only being a comedian if that’s not what he wants. It’s possible for people to branch out. I have never personally gotten the impression that Dan is educated enough to start making political commentary, at least not on American politics, however, he does have some unique expertise from his experience as a YouTuber and social media influencer, which he could definitely use to speak about more serious topics. For example, Pewdiepie now has a series called “Pew News” where he talks about current events using his knowledge of new media, which is something he is arguably one of the foremost experts in based on his success in the field. I think with videos like “Daniel and Depression,” Dan has demonstrated that he is capable of doing the research necessary to speak on a topic responsibly, but unlike Felix, I don’t think Dan has an interest in being controversial and politics are almost always controversial.

If anything, the reaction to the Bernie Sanders bath picture demonstrates to me that Dan’s audience isn’t mature enough to handle him making serious political or social commentary. Dan is much more adept at social media than anyone here on Tumblr and has spent the past ten years on YouTube where something like the thumbnail of a video can have a huge effect on its visibility and income. I don’t think for a second he is naive enough to not think posting a picture that featured a political candidate wouldn’t spark some conversation and he made the choice to post it. It definitely implies a greater level of support for certain ideas and a certain person than liking the tweet the other day and while I think the tweet should have been a non-issue, I felt the need to comment on this because, as an American, I am very aware of the effect Bernie Sanders has had on political realities in my country and when Dan brought up the topic (which he did), I felt it was my duty and responsibility to at least share information as to why he is a poor candidate to help make sure people have access to the information.

That being said, all we can objectively tell from the picture was that Dan was educating himself on American politics, so I don’t think he deserves backlash, but I also don’t think people discussing why or why not Bernie Sanders is a good candidate deserve backlash either (not that I have received any personally). I think the immaturity of the phandom becomes apparent when the whole conversation about a political candidate’s merit (which is reasonable and important) becomes defined by people either attacking or defending Dan. There shouldn’t be a need for either. Even if Dan comes out and says, “I, Dan Howell, endorse Bernie Sanders,” I don’t think there should be a need for either. People should be able to share and discuss ideas and learn and grow and agree and disagree without it becoming adversarial “drama.” Trust me when I say, Dan is perfectly aware not everyone is going to agree with him politically and seeing as I just watched the director’s commentary for II yesterday and he said he was very passionate about social justice, I think he would be very open to and encouraging of respectful conversation on how best to achieve that. Still, until the phandom can learn to separate disagreeing with someone’s idea and attacking their character (and when each is appropriate) and the difference between their assumptions and facts when it comes to Dan and who he is and the messages he is putting out, I don’t think he should touch any social or political issues with a ten foot pole.
